,The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of CVA and hemorrhagic evolution, AV and MV valves, and recent GI bleed. She was transferred from another hospital with mitral valve thrombus and acute congestive heart failure secondary to the thrombus and atrial fibrillation. The patient has a high gradient between the left atrium (LA) and left ventricle (LV), indicating poor filling due to functional stenosis caused by the thrombus.
The assessment and plan include the following:
1. Acute Congestive Heart Failure: Start low-dose Metoprolol IV for heart rate control to improve forward flow. Use Lasix as needed.

2. Prosthetic Mitral Valve Thrombus: Echocardiogram confirms thrombus on the prosthetic MV valve, and fluoroscopy shows one leaflet that is fixed. The patient had a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) during admission three weeks ago that was negative for valvular thrombus. TEE shows gradient pressures of Mitral 28/(mean)18 and Aortic 45/(mean)23. Given the patient's recent hemorrhagic stroke and GI bleed, management will be challenging. The patient resumed coumadin on transfer to rehabilitation to prevent further clots. Consult with surgery regarding the patient's candidacy for future surgery. Continue Heparin gtt.
3. GI Bleed: Unclear source, likely lower GI. HCT dropped"
TEE showed thrombus increasing in size.  Family meeting: plan not to
escalate care.  Would make CMO if worsening.  GI recommended CT scan
when more stable and following lactate.  Tachycardia responded well to
5 mg metoprolol bolus in AM and PM.  Hypoxic -> ABG, CXR, CPAP o/n.
Tele: HR improved with metoprolol.  Desats at 11 PM.  Prior to CPAP.
Changes to medical and family history:
Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below
HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no
pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma.
CARDIAC: RRR, with loud S2, crescendo-decrescendo murmur at LUSB
LUNGS: Diffuse rales in posterior lung fields, obscured by BiPAP
ABDOMEN: Soft, RLQ TTP.  Voluntary guarding.  No rebound.
EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits.
Neuro:  Moves all 4 with commands.  [**1-23**] handgrip on R, 0/5 on L.
Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ PT 2+
Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ PT 2+
Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:16.1/58.9/1.4, CK / CKMB /
Troponin-T:58//0.05, ALT / AST:33/62, Alk Phos / T Bili:99/0.4, Amylase
Eos:0.9 %, Lactic Acid:2.7 mmol/L, Albumin:2.9 g/dL, LDH:462 IU/L,
Ca++:8.1 mg/dL, Mg++:2.1 mg/dL, PO4:1.8 mg/dL
The left atrium is dilated. Mild spontaneous echo contrast is seen in
the body of the left atrium. Moderate to severe spontaneous echo
contrast is present in the left atrial appendage. The left atrial
appendage emptying velocity is depressed (<0.2m/s). A probable thrombus
is seen in the tip of the left atrial appendage. No atrial septal
defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. There are simple atheroma in the
ascending aorta. There are simple atheroma in the aortic arch. There
are simple atheroma in the descending thoracic aorta up to 35cm from
the incisor. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are moderately thickened.
There is severe aortic valve stenosis (area 0.6cm2 by planimetry).
Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. [Due to acoustic shadowing, the
severity of aortic regurgitation may be significantly UNDERestimated.]
A mechanical mitral valve prosthesis is present. There is extensive
thrombus around the ring of the prosthesis that measures at least 3.4cm
by 1.1cm by dimension. There is a highly mobile component of the
thrombus that measure 1.9cm x 0.5cm that prolapses through the mitral
valve orifice. The anterior/septal mitral valve leaflet is completely
immobile. The posterior/lateral leaflet moves well. The gradients
across the mitral valve is suggestive of severe valvular mitral
stenosis. A tricuspid valve annuloplasty ring is present with trace
tricuspid regurgitation. There is no pericardial effusion.
Impression: Extensive thrombus around the mechanical mitral prosthesis
causing severe mitral stenosis. Severe aortic stenosis. Thrombus in the
CXR: worsening infilterates involving midzones of both lungs suggests
multifocal pneumonia or unusual pattern of progression of heart
remainder of the study including the lines and tubes are unchanged.

,Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of cardiovascular accident (CVA), hemorrhagic evolution, atrioventricular (AV) and mitral (MV) valves, thrombosis, and gastrointestinal (GI) bleed. She has been admitted to the ICU with multiple medical complications.

- Prosthetic Mitral Valve Thrombus: The patient has an echocardiogram consistent with thrombus on the prosthetic MV valve. She had a TTE during admission three weeks ago that was negative for valvular thrombus. Given the patient's recent hemorrhagic stroke and GI bleed, the management will be difficult. The patient is likely a poor surgical candidate.

- Acute Congestive Heart Failure: Secondary to Mitral valve thrombus and atrial fibrillation. The patient has a high gradient between the left atrium (LA) and left ventricle (LV), also not filling well secondary to functional stenosis secondary to thrombus. Good response to low-dose IV metoprolol.
- GI bleed: Unclear source, likely lower GI. HCT dropped from 29 to 25 this AM and was subsequently transfused. Hct responded appropriately but then came back down.
- Atrial Fibrillation: Poorly rate controlled. Dig level 1.1, likely toxic level in this patient in light of her EKG changes.
TEE showed thrombus increasing in size.  Family meeting: plan not to
escalate care.  Would make CMO if worsening.  GI recommended CT scan
when more stable and following lactate.  Tachycardia responded well to
5 mg metoprolol bolus in AM and PM.  Hypoxic -> ABG, CXR, CPAP o/n.

,The patient is a 66-year-old female who has had a cerebrovascular accident (CVA) with a hemorrhagic evolution, atrioventricular (AV) and mitral valve (MV) thrombosis, and gastrointestinal (GI) bleed. She has been transferred from another hospital with a prosthetic MV and is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU).

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 38.2 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 88 beats per minute, blood pressure of 86/49 mmHg, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient is in atrial fibrillation.

Her physical examination reveals rales in the posterior lung fields, right lower quadrant tenderness with voluntary guarding, and no femoral bruits. Neurological examination shows movement of all four limbs with commands but decreased grip strength on the left side.

Laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count of 20.8 thousand cells/mm3, hemoglobin of 7.9 g/dL, sodium of 131 mg/dL, potassium of 4.6 mEq/L, creatinine of 1.2 mg/dL, and blood urea nitrogen of 24 mg/dL. Coagulation studies show a prothrombin time (PT) of 14.9 seconds, partial thromboplastin time (PTT) of 41.1 seconds, and international normalized ratio"

The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of cerebral vascular accident (CVA) and hemorrhagic evolution. She has prosthetic aortic and mitral valves and was transferred from another hospital with mitral valve thrombosis and gastrointestinal (GI) bleed. The patient has been in the ICU since admission.
The patient has been on heparin drip, but it was discontinued due to bleeding complications. The family is considering comfort measures only (CMO) if the patient worsens.

The patient has multiple medical conditions including congestive heart failure (CHF), atrial fibrillation (AF), GI bleed, and hypothyroidism. She also has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) but had normal coronary arteries on catheterization.

The patient's recent lab results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC), low hemoglobin (Hct), and elevated lactate levels. The echocardiogram shows a thrombus on the prosthetic mitral valve and fixed leaflet.

1. Prosthetic Mitral Valve Thrombus: Continue heparin drip and consider surgical intervention if possible. The patient is likely a poor surgical candidate due to recent hemorrhagic stroke and GI bleed.
